author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Hello, I am an automated registration bot. I help manage the registration process by checking your registration against a set of [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). If all these guidelines are met, this pull request will be merged automatically, completing your registration. It is **strongly recommended** to follow the guidelines, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

## 1. New package registration

Please make sure that you have read the [package naming guidelines](https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1).

## 2. [AutoMerge Guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/) are all met! ✅

Your new package registration met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

## 3. To pause or stop registration

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.

_Tip: You can edit blocking comments to add `[noblock]` in order to unblock auto-merging._

<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

[noblock] Please avoid changing the version number when fixing automerge issues. That way, it will update the existing PR instead of creating a new one. Would you like to revert to v1.0.0 and try to update https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/131656? I would then close this PR in favor of the previous one.

Going back to 1.0.0 sounds great. However, the reason why I changed to
v1.0.1 is that, after fixing the automerge error (a [compat] issue) and
re-submitting the registration request, I got another automerge error
saying

     "Error while trying to register: "Tag with name v1.0.0 already exists
and points to a different commit"

So I changed Project.toml to v1.0.1 and it went through.
Joao



On Sat, May 24, 2025 at 5:43 PM Michael Goerz ***@***.***>
wrote:

> *goerz* left a comment (JuliaRegistries/General#131663)
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/131663#issuecomment-2907529414>
>
> [noblock] Please avoid changing the version number when fixing automerge
> issues. That way, it will update the existing PR instead of creating a new
> one. Would you like to revert to v1.0.0 and try to update #131656
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/131656>? I would then
> close this PR in favor of the previous one.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/131663#issuecomment-2907529414>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AC3N7NNFBIRJ74PI4CU4BEL3AEG27AVCNFSM6AAAAAB53BXEWCVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZDSMBXGUZDSNBRGQ>
> .
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

You must not create tags before the registration of a version goes through. Actually, I would _strongly_ recommend not creating tags for Julia projects manually at all, but to use [TagBot](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/TagBot) instead. The way Julia packages are intended to work is that you register a new version using the Registrator. Once the registration goes through, TagBot will be notified and create the tag in your repository.

Please delete all of the existing ["releases"](https://github.com/HespanhaPublic/PersistentCache.jl/releases) and [tags](https://github.com/HespanhaPublic/PersistentCache.jl/tags) from the repository, see, e.g. the instructions in [this YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h-FE0OUjeH4). Install TagBot according to the [setup instructions](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/TagBot?tab=readme-ov-file#setup). Then, retrigger the registration again for `v1.0.0`, e.g., by commenting `@Registrator register` on the commit that you want to be tagged as `v1.0.0`.

If, for some reason, you do not want to use TagBot (you _really_ should, though), you can still create and push tags manually, but only _after_ the registration has gone through.

Just did what you suggested: erased tags, installed TagBot, went back to
1.0.0, and retriggered registration.
It looks like all is going smoothly.

Thanks for your help!
Joao
